items.title: DeepSeek banned from Australian government devices over national security concerns
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI chatbot, is banned from all federal government devices in Australia due to national security risks.
- The directive was signed by the home affairs department secretary after intelligence agency advice.
- The Albanese government emphasizes protective actions regarding national security and potential threats posed by AI technologies.
- Australia joins other countries like Taiwan and Italy in banning DeepSeek from government devices.
- Similar to previous bans on TikTok, discussions and considerations regarding DeepSeek's risks are ongoing within government systems.

items.title: The 15 best PlayStation 5 games to play in 2025
items.summary:
- Sony's PlayStation 5 has produced top-quality games since its launch, with both in-house and indie developers showcasing their creativity.
- Notable PS5 games include:
  - **Astro Bot**: A platformer featuring a space robot on a quest to reassemble his ship.
  - **Baldur’s Gate 3**: Celebrated as a modern RPG landmark, offers a deep narrative akin to tabletop gaming.
  - **Cocoon**: An innovative puzzle game featuring inter-world traversal.
  - **Death Stranding**: Known for its unique narrative and delivery mechanics in a post-apocalyptic setting.
  - **Demon’s Souls**: A remastered classic offering a dark and challenging gaming experience.
  - **Elden Ring**: A large open-world game from the makers of Dark Souls, praised for its design.
  - **Final Fantasy VII Remake**: A reimagining of the iconic RPG with updated visuals and gameplay.
  - **God of War Ragnarök**: The sequel that explores mythological themes and character depth.
  - **Gran Turismo 7**: Features stunning graphics and details for vehicle enthusiasts.
  - **Helldivers 2**: A co-op shooter drawing inspiration from science-fiction classics.
  - **The Last of Us Parts I and II Remastered**: Offers updated graphics and a compelling narrative.
  - **Marvel’s Spider-Man 2**: Features a collaborative narrative between Peter Parker and Miles Morales against iconic villains.

items.title: 'I'm a bit lost now': Daisy the AI bot speaks to scammer – video
items.summary:
- O2 has launched an AI bot named Daisy to combat phone scammers.
- Daisy is designed to waste scammers' time by acting confused and reminiscing.
- The initiative illustrates the potential of AI in fighting fraud.

items.title: China unveils US tariffs and Google investigation in response to Trump levies
items.summary:
- Donald Trump imposed 10% tariffs on China, prompting retaliatory actions from Beijing.
- China launched an anti-trust investigation into Google and announced various tariffs on US exports including coal and crude oil.
- Export controls were imposed on critical minerals, and US companies PVH Group and Illumina were added to China's unreliable entity list.
- The US scrapped an exemption for exports valued under $800, affecting popular Chinese retailers.
- Trump postponed tariffs on Mexico and Canada after negotiations, amid global economic concerns.

items.title: 'Dear, did you say pastry?': meet the ‘AI granny’ driving scammers up the wall
items.summary:
- An AI bot named 'Daisy' simulates an elderly grandmother to frustrate phone scammers.
- Daisy uses ambivalence and confusion to waste the fraudsters' time, engaging them in conversations about knitting and pastries.
- The initiative aims to raise awareness about scams rather than rolling out the AI widely, with the potential for future versions to adopt different accents and personas.

items.title: AI systems could be ‘caused to suffer’ if consciousness achieved, says research
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- A group of over 100 AI experts signed an open letter expressing concerns about the risks of developing AI with feelings or self-awareness irresponsibly.
- The letter outlines five principles for responsible research into AI consciousness, including prioritizing research on understanding AI consciousness and preventing mistreatment.
- The researchers warn that creating large numbers of conscious AI systems could lead to significant moral and ethical issues, including the potential for such systems to experience suffering.

items.title: Critic of Italy-Libya migration pact told he was target of Israeli spyware
items.summary:
- A Sweden-based Libyan activist, Husam El Gomati, was targeted with military-grade spyware, raising concerns about European governments' cyberweapons.
- The spyware, linked to Paragon Solutions, was discovered after El Gomati criticized Italy's actions regarding illegal migration to Libya.
- WhatsApp notified El Gomati of the breach, which affects his ability to protect confidential sources.
- Paragon Solutions has government clients and previously had contracts with US immigration services, now under review.
- El Gomati has reported on a case involving Osama Najim, linked to serious human rights violations and released due to a technicality.

items.title: Civilization VII review – your empire strikes back in glorious new detail
items.summary:
- Civilization VII offers a revamped gameplay experience with players guiding different leaders through distinct historical ages.
- Each leader has unique strengths and attributes, and players can select different nations to control in each age, maintaining progress between switches.
- The game incorporates RPG elements, including skill trees and legacy targets, making it more accessible to modern players.
- Diplomatic interactions are enhanced with a new influence currency, allowing for shared events and various forms of subterfuge.
- The visual graphics are greatly improved, featuring vibrant landscapes and animated battles, enhancing the immersive experience of empire building.

items.title: OpenAI launches ‘deep research’ tool that it says can match research analyst
items.summary:
- OpenAI announces a new AI tool called 'deep research' that generates reports in about 10 minutes, matching research analyst output.
- The tool uses OpenAI's latest model, o3, to analyze and synthesize information from hundreds of sources.
- 'Deep research' is designed for professionals in finance, science, and engineering, and can handle tasks related to purchases like cars and furniture.
- The tool is currently available in the US to Pro tier users with a limit of 100 queries per month, priced at $200.
- Concerns have been raised about users relying on the tool's outputs without sufficient verification.

items.title: Keir Starmer changed ‘dangerously obvious’ email address in 2022 after Russian hacking
items.summary:
- Keir Starmer stopped using a personal email account in 2022 after a suspected hack by a Russian group.
- The breach notification came shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, according to a book about Starmer.
- Staff were instructed not to use the email address following a warning from the National Cyber Security Centre regarding potential sensitive information theft.
- The previous email address was criticized as 'dangerously obvious' and lacked two-factor authentication, which was addressed in the new account.
- Similar hacking incidents involving Russian groups have targeted other UK figures, including emails from former MI6 director Sir Richard Dearlove.

items.title: AI to revolutionise fundamental physics and ‘could show how universe will end’
items.summary:
- Advanced AI expected to transform fundamental physics and provide insights into the universe's fate.
- Prof Mark Thomson, incoming director general of CERN, highlights AI's role in particle physics akin to Google DeepMind's achievements in protein structure predictions.
- AI aids in detecting rare particle events related to mass acquisition post-big bang, potential universe collapse.
- CERN advocates for the Future Circular Collider, despite skepticism about funding and results.
- Major upgrades to the LHC planned by 2030 to increase beam intensity significantly.
- Aiming to produce two Higgs bosons simultaneously for groundbreaking measurements of Higgs self-coupling, essential for understanding universe's mass acquisition mechanism.
- Higgs self-coupling could imply future universe transitions but poses no immediate risk to humanity.
- AI enhances LHC operations, refining data collection and interpretation, achieving results far beyond previous expectations.

items.title: Elon Musk’s Doge team granted ‘full access’ to federal payment system
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's 'department of government efficiency' has gained access to the federal payment system, affecting millions of Americans.
- Senator Ron Wyden confirmed that this access includes sensitive data like social security and Medicare benefits.
- The access was granted by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent amid concerns of potential conflicts of interest and national security risks due to Musk's business ties.

items.title: Why can’t I stop looking at myself on video calls?
items.summary:
- The article addresses the obsessive tendency some individuals experience while looking at themselves on video calls.
- A reader, Daniel Brown from London, poses a question about this phenomenon.
- The article is part of a series where readers respond to each other's queries.

items.title: The AI business model is built on hype. That’s the real reason the tech bros fear DeepSeek
items.summary:
- The launch of DeepSeek R1, a Chinese generative AI, disrupted the tech world, causing stock declines and worries about U.S. AI supremacy.
- DeepSeek is technically similar to existing large language models like ChatGPT but performs poorly, with a 30% false claim rate and a high non-response rate due to censorship.
- The impact of DeepSeek lies more in its economic implications for AI, being cheaper and open-source, potentially democratizing AI technology and challenging Silicon Valley's narrative of AI as a miraculous achievement.

items.title: Source Code by Bill Gates review – growing pains of a computer geek
items.summary:
- The book explores the early life of Bill Gates from 1955 to the founding of Microsoft in 1975.
- It discusses the support and pressure Gates received from his parents and the challenges he faced as a gifted but socially awkward child.
- Gates reflects on his schooling at Lakeside, where he first encountered computers and began programming with his peers, including Paul Allen.
- After dropping out of Harvard, Gates co-founded Microsoft, marking the beginning of his rise to wealth and power.
- The book hints at a deeper narrative about Gates's later life and impact, which may be covered in a sequel.

items.title: AI tools used for child sexual abuse images targeted in Home Office crackdown
items.summary:
- Britain is set to become the first country to impose laws against the use of [AI tools for creating child sexual abuse images](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2024/oct/18/artificial-intelligence-child-sexual-abuse-imagery-watchdog-iwf).
- New legislation will make it illegal to possess, create, or distribute AI tools for generating such material, with prison sentences of up to five years for offenders.
- Possession of instructional manuals on using AI for abuse will also be illegal, facing potential three-year prison terms.
- Website operators sharing abusive materials will be targeted under the new laws, alongside strengthened powers for the Border Force to inspect digital devices of suspected offenders.
- Reports of AI-generated child sexual abuse imagery have surged from 51 in 2023 to 245 last year, as per the Internet Watch Foundation (IWF).
- Concerns grow that AI tools could normalize child sexual abuse, with police warning of a direct link between viewing such imagery and real-life abuse.
- Technology Secretary Peter Kyle emphasized the need for urgent legislative action to keep children safe from AI-related exploitation.

items.title: ‘I lost 10 years of my life’: how UK betting giant’s unlawful marketing kept suicidal gambler hooked
items.summary:
- Sam logged into his online betting account on 15 August 2018, gambling five days’ worth of wages despite being deep in debt.
- Sky Betting & Gaming labeled him as a ‘high value’ customer and sent targeted promotional emails, prompting further gambling. 
- A landmark legal ruling found that the targeting was unlawful, as Sam was not in a state to consent due to his compulsive gambling behavior.
- The judge concluded that Sam's decision-making was impaired and highlighted Sky Bet's failure to identify at-risk customers for intervention.

items.title: Was this the week DeepSeek started the slow unwinding of the AI bet?
items.summary:
- At 2.16pm California time, billionaire Marc Andreessen named DeepSeek R1 as AI's 'Sputnik moment'.
- A Chinese startup released a new chatbot matching the performance of leading American models at reduced costs.
- This development caused Nvidia shares to plunge nearly $600bn, indicating fears over US tech supremacy in AI.
- DeepSeek's app quickly became the most downloaded free app in the US and UK app stores.
- Concerns arose from the censorship of sensitive topics in China, affecting the model's responsiveness.
- Experts expressed awe at DeepSeek's innovations, which challenged traditional AI development approaches, emphasizing skills over extensive computing power.
- The model was initially blocked from app stores in Italy over data protection concerns.
- US officials, including President Trump, called for increased focus on AI competitiveness amid DeepSeek's emergence.

items.title: AI is not just powerful. What’s really worrying is that DeepSeek has made it cheap, too
items.summary:
- Nvidia experienced a historic one-day market cap loss of $600bn, affecting many tech companies.
- Chinese startup DeepSeek launched R1, a cheap and effective AI assistant, costing $5.58m to develop.
- R1 outperforms competitors in efficiency and has drawn significant interest from users and investors alike.
- Marc Andreessen called R1 AI's "Sputnik moment," indicating its potential to disrupt US tech.
- DeepSeek’s success reflects China's advancement in AI technology and raises concerns for US companies.
- The rollout of R1 shows low-cost AI models could transform the industry, similar to past technological revolutions.

items.title: A man stalked a professor for six years. Then he used AI chatbots to lure strangers to her home
DeepSeek, ChatGPT, Grok … which is the best AI assistant? We put them to the test
items.summary:
- OpenAI’s ChatGPT, still leading in brand recognition, faced challenges with complex prompts at first but ultimately complied, producing a Shakespearean sonnet. 
- DeepSeek, a newly released Chinese chatbot on January 20, showcased impressive features but declined to discuss sensitive political topics like Tiananmen Square, indicating cultural and operational limitations. 
- Other chatbots tested included Grok, which humorously handled sensitive topics, and Gemini, which showed competence in interpreting images but struggled with specfic queries.

items.title: ‘Are we dating the same guy?’: Women turn to Facebook to uncover cheating and violence
items.summary:
- The Facebook group 'Are We Dating the Same Guy?' allows women to share information about men, especially focusing on potential cheaters and abusers.
- Groups are regional, with membership sizes varying from 164,000 in NYC to around 10,000 in Sydney; a UK group covers all regions.
- The groups serve as a resource for women to warn each other about dangerous men and discuss experiences with emotional abuse and narcissism.
- Some experts warn about the risks of backlash from men discovered through these groups, including legal threats and retaliatory actions.
- The conversation surrounding the Domestic Violence Disclosure Scheme (DVDS) emphasizes the importance of police disclosing information about abusive partners.
- Despite the potential dangers, the existence of the groups reflects a gap left by state services, showcasing women's solidarity and resourcefulness in protecting one another.

items.title: Italian investigative journalist targeted on WhatsApp by Israeli spyware
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- An Italian investigative journalist, Francesco Cancellato, reported receiving a notification about being targeted by Israeli spyware from Paragon Solutions.
- He is known for exposing fascist activities within Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s far-right party.
- WhatsApp revealed on a Friday that 90 journalists and others had been targeted and discovered the spyware's activity in December.
- Paragon's spyware, Graphite, can infect devices without user interaction through group chats and PDFs.
- Cancellato has not been informed of any investigations against him and considers the incident a significant violation of privacy.

items.title: OpenAI to release new artificial intelligence model for free
items.summary:
- OpenAI is launching a new AI model called o3-mini for free in response to competition from China's DeepSeek.
- The o3-mini model offers reasoning capabilities to free users, launching on 31 January 2025.
- DeepSeek’s R1 chatbot has disrupted the market, impacting investor confidence in US tech companies.
- Users on ChatGPT Pro will have unlimited access to o3-mini; Plus users will receive higher usage limits than free users.
- The model is said to match its predecessor, o1, in several areas but offers faster response times at a lower cost.

items.title: WhatsApp says journalists and civil society members were targets of Israeli spyware
items.summary:
- Nearly 100 journalists and civil society members using WhatsApp were targeted by Israeli spyware from Paragon Solutions.
- The attack, characterized as a “zero-click” breach, indicates users didn't need to interact with malicious content to be compromised.
- WhatsApp has alerted affected users and sent a cease and desist letter to Paragon, exploring legal options while disrupting the attacks in December.
- Paragon’s spyware, Graphite, is comparable to NSO Group’s Pegasus, offering extensive access to infected devices, compromising messages sent through encrypted applications.
- The infection was believed to have been delivered via a malicious PDF file sent to group chat members.

items.title: Oh, I’m sorry, tech bros – did DeepSeek copy your work? I can hardly imagine your distress
items.author: Marina Hyde
items.summary:
- OpenAI's Sam Altman expressed concern over DeepSeek potentially misusing ChatGPT for their new AI project.
- The Chinese hedge fund DeepSeek's actions led to turmoil in the tech stock market.
- Altman's statement on this situation highlights the ongoing discussion about intellectual property in the AI landscape.
- The article critiques Silicon Valley's response to perceived threats from China while ignoring similar practices within its own industry.

items.title: Indiana Jones and the Great Circle fulfilled all my Nazi-punching fantasies
items.summary:
- The game opens with a warning against Nazism, promoting an anti-fascist narrative.
- It involves combat with caricatured fascist enemies, depicted as incompetent and morally repugnant.
- The player experiences excitement in defeating Nazis, almost reflecting real-world frustrations.
- The author critiques the slower-paced archaeological segments compared to action sequences.
- Immersive action sequences include skiing down mountains and escaping bomb attacks in Shanghai.
- The game evokes real-life parallels with rising far-right ideologies, illustrating a satire on current events.

items.title: Source Code: My Beginnings by Bill Gates review – refreshingly frank
items.summary:
- Bill Gates reflects on his early life and career in the first volume of his memoir trilogy, covering from 1955 to the founding of Microsoft in 1975.
- Gates describes his childhood in Seattle, early computer experiences, and his partnership with Paul Allen.
- The book emphasizes Gates's gratitude for mentors, acknowledges his upbringing privileges, and explores personal losses, including a friend's death in a mountaineering accident.

items.title: New technology could make fridges cheaper and more eco-friendly
items.summary:
- A report indicates new technology could reduce refrigerator costs and enhance eco-friendliness.
- Refrigerators accounted for about 4% of global electricity consumption in 2019, highlighting the significance of energy-saving innovations.
- Research from Huazhong University shows that thermogalvanic technology offers a sustainable alternative to traditional refrigeration cooling methods.
- The technology could enable widespread carbon neutrality if adopted broadly, as stated by senior author Jiangjiang Duan.
- Thermogalvanic cells generate electricity using heat from reversible chemical reactions, representing potential for various applications, including wearable devices.
- Optimizations in chemical use improved cooling power of hydrogalvanic cells by 70%.
- Refrigerators contribute significantly to greenhouse gases, with substantial emissions stemming from their electricity use and gas leakages.
- Future research aims to optimize designs and expand commercial applications of thermogalvanic technology.

items.title: An Update on Our Family review – these influencers’ murky tale makes you long to end the internet
items.summary:
- The documentary follows the Stauffer family, a former successful family vlogging couple, exploring the implications of their online persona and monetizing their family experiences.
- The narrative intensifies when they adopt Huxley, a boy with special needs from China, and later remove him from their videos, leading to public outrage and conspiracy theories.
- The film raises ethical questions about filming children without consent, the nature of parasocial relationships, and the motives behind sharing personal lives online.

items.title: Apple to report earnings for first quarter of 2025
items.summary:
- Apple will report earnings for Q1 2025 after markets close on Thursday.
- Analysts estimate quarterly revenue at $124.39 billion, a 4% year-over-year growth, with earnings per share at $2.35.
- Investors are focused on Apple's developments in artificial intelligence, which have progressed slowly and received mixed reviews, especially for the AI-powered product launched in October.
- The tech sector has faced challenges, with many stocks tumbling after a Chinese AI company's app topped the App Store, causing significant losses in market value.
- Despite market fluctuations, Apple's stock remained stable earlier in the week, though its prices have fallen about 8% due to decreasing phone sales in China.
- Apple’s AI has faced issues, including inaccuracies in notifications, leading to complaints from the BBC regarding misinformation generated by the tech.

items.title: Citizen Sleeper 2: Starward Vector review – we’re putting together a crew
items.summary:
- Citizen Sleeper 2 is set in a richly portrayed future of outer space life, featuring various characters and storylines.
- Players assume the role of a Sleeper, a robot with a digitized human mind, and face challenges from a gang boss named Laine.
- The game expands the setting across multiple space stations with a time-sensitive escape mechanic.
- Introduces a dice system that impacts gameplay, including the potential for dice to break and affect mission outcomes.
- Players can recruit crew members for support, enhancing gameplay with specialized abilities.
- Although larger than its predecessor, the game feels less intimate, with scattered activities across locations.
- The characters are well-developed, contributing to the emotional depth of the game despite its bleak themes.
- Release date is set for 31 January 2025.

items.title: Get ahead of the tech curve: aim for Hangzhou, not Silicon Valley | Brief letters
items.author: John Lowery, Dr Jonathan J Ross, Laura Ashton, Emma Tait, Dr Richard O’Brien, Neil Hanson
items.summary:
- Rachel Reeves proposes creating "Europe’s Silicon Valley," but the author suggests looking towards Hangzhou instead.
- Hangzhou is home to DeepSeek, which significantly impacted US tech stock values.
- The article contains letters addressing various topics including a vertebra found online and experiences starting holidays at airport bars.

items.title: SoftBank ‘in talks’ to invest up to $25bn in OpenAI
items.summary:
- SoftBank is in discussions to invest between $15bn and $25bn in OpenAI, potentially becoming its largest financial backer.
- The investment follows a previous funding round that valued OpenAI at $157bn, which included support from Microsoft.
- SoftBank and OpenAI recently partnered with Oracle to launch Stargate, a large AI infrastructure project, with an initial investment goal of $100bn.
- Claims have emerged regarding the financial capacity of Stargate's backers, prompting a response from OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman.

items.title: Meta agrees to pay Trump $25m for suspending accounts over Capitol riots
items.summary:
- Meta has settled a lawsuit with Donald Trump for $25 million over the suspension of his accounts after the January 6 Capitol riot.
- $22 million of the settlement will fund Trump’s presidential library, while the rest covers legal fees and other plaintiffs.
- Zuckerberg’s decision to suspend Trump’s accounts was due to perceived risks during civil unrest; Trump has since reinstated on Facebook and Instagram after a two-year suspension.

items.title: Microsoft to report fourth-quarter earnings amid uproar over DeepSeek’s AI
items.summary:
- Microsoft is set to report its second-quarter earnings for fiscal year 2025 on Wednesday, facing scrutiny over AI spending amid the DeepSeek controversy.
- Wall Street anticipates $3.11 earnings per share and $68.9bn in revenue, an increase from the previous year’s $2.93 a share and $62bn.
- The $600bn drop in Nvidia's market capitalization highlights the impacts of DeepSeek's AI model achieving similar results to US firms at lower costs.
- Microsoft and OpenAI are probing whether DeepSeek-linked groups accessed OpenAI’s data improperly.
- David Sacks of the White House suggested DeepSeek may have stolen US intellectual property related to AI.
- Microsoft retains a “right of first refusal” with OpenAI following changes in their partnership status.

items.title: Tesla to report fourth-quarter earnings amid declining car delivery numbers
items.summary:
- Tesla will report earnings for Q4 2024 on Wednesday, with analysts predicting $0.62 EPS and $27.22 billion in revenue.
- The company has faced a decline in annual vehicle deliveries for the first time, struggling against cheaper competitors like BYD.
- European subsidies for electric cars are decreasing, and Tesla's vehicle registrations in Europe fell 24% in October.
- The recently released Cybertruck has not compensated for declining demand for older models, and Tesla's autonomous driving software is under federal investigation.

items.title: DeepSeek blocked from some app stores in Italy amid questions on data use
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI platform, is blocked from some app stores in Italy due to data handling concerns.
- Italian and Irish regulators are demanding answers about citizens’ data usage by DeepSeek.
- The app was reportedly removed from Apple and Google stores in Italy, with users receiving unavailability messages.
- The Italian regulator, Garante, is investigating compliance with GDPR regulations and has given DeepSeek 20 days to respond.
- DeepSeek claims to store personal information on secure servers in China and to use data to comply with legal obligations.
- The UK government is monitoring potential national security threats from DeepSeek.
- OpenAI is investigating allegations that DeepSeek may have used its AI models improperly.

items.title: Meta to report fourth-quarter earnings amid DeepSeek mania and ballooning AI investments
items.summary:
- Meta's earnings report for Q4 2024 is due after US stock markets close on Wednesday.
- Mark Zuckerberg plans to invest $60-$65 billion in AI infrastructure for 2025, up from $50 billion previously projected.
- Meta is facing competition from new AI player DeepSeek, prompting an increase in AI development efforts.
- The company launched a more personalized AI assistant and claims its AI is the most used virtual assistant.
- Analysts anticipate a defensive stance during the earnings call, focusing on concerns about eliminating third-party fact-checking programs.
- Meta will also address workforce reductions, targeting low performers with a 5% staff cut.
- Reports indicate Reality Labs achieved significant growth in 2024, with a 40% increase in sales and users, alongside a leadership shake-up expected.

items.title: What video game ephemera tell us about ourselves
items.summary:
- The Video Game History Foundation is sharing a digital archive of about 1,500 games magazines starting January 30.
- The National Videogame Museum focuses on collecting materials that reflect individual gaming experiences and stories behind collections.
- The cultural relevance of video game materials is growing as institutions begin to collect these artifacts, with 87% of classic video games considered critically endangered.
- Personal experiences with gaming can hold significant emotional value, as reflected in the author’s nostalgic recollections of their gaming collection and memories associated with it.

items.title: What International AI Safety report says on jobs, climate, cyberwar and more
items.summary:
- The International AI Safety report highlights significant challenges posed by rapidly advancing AI technologies.
- The report warns of profound job impacts due to capable AI agents, with potential for new jobs but also significant job losses in advanced economies.
- AI's energy consumption contributes to 1% of greenhouse gas emissions, with increasing demands from datacentres, raising environmental concerns.
- Concerns over loss of control of powerful AI systems are noted, with varying opinions on the likelihood of negative outcomes.
- AI models could create advanced bioweapons, but there are uncertainties about their use by untrained individuals.
- Cybersecurity threats from AI include autonomous bots finding software vulnerabilities, but attacks cannot currently be carried out independently.
- The report discusses the malicious use of deepfakes, noting a lack of data to fully measure the impact and challenges in addressing them.

items.title: Chinese firms ‘distilling’ US AI models to create rival products, warns OpenAI
items.summary:
- OpenAI warns that Chinese startups are using its technology to develop competing products, particularly a chatbot by DeepSeek.
- DeepSeek’s chatbot launch caused a market drop, wiping $1 trillion from AI-linked US tech stocks due to its claims of lower operational costs.
- OpenAI, alongside Microsoft, is investigating unauthorized use of its technology through 'distillation'.
- OpenAI’s CEO expressed initial admiration for DeepSeek but later highlighted evidence of potential intellectual property theft.
- US government agencies, including the Navy, are assessing the national security implications of DeepSeek's AI technology.

items.title: DeepSeek advances could heighten safety risk, says ‘godfather’ of AI
items.author: Yoshua Bengio
items.summary:
- A report by AI experts warns that systems like DeepSeek could increase safety risks in AI.
- Yoshua Bengio highlights concerns over AI advancements by the Chinese startup DeepSeek, suggesting competition may detract from safety priorities.
- The International AI Safety report, led by Bengio, includes input from 96 experts and outlines risks such as potential misuse in cyber attacks and deepfakes.
- AI systems now capable of generating harmful instructions autonomously, although executing attacks remains a challenge.
- The report notes increased risks from both open-source and closed-source AI models, emphasizing the need for regulatory intervention.

items.title: Rise and shine with the seven best sunrise alarm clocks, tried and tested
items.summary:
- Sunrise alarm clocks help align waking with the natural circadian rhythm, enhancing health and mood.
- Key models tested include Lumie Bodyclock Spark 100, Philips SmartSleep, and Beurer Wake-Up Light WL50.
- Models certified for light therapy specifically target conditions like Seasonal Affective Disorder.
- The Lumie Bodyclock Spark 100 is praised for its realistic sunrise simulation and design.
- Philips SmartSleep offers easy setup and various audio options but is on the pricier side.
- The Beurer WL50 is highlighted as ideal for couples, catering to dual wake-up needs.

items.title: ‘Headed for technofascism’: the rightwing roots of Silicon Valley
items.summary:
- The article explores the historical rightwing roots of Silicon Valley, highlighting concerns from the 1990s about a potential "technofascism" emerging within the tech industry.
- It focuses on George Gilder, a key figure in Silicon Valley's reactionary movement, who promoted a vision of entrepreneurship tied to traditional gender roles and a critique of the welfare state.
- The narrative discusses media portrayal of tech entrepreneurs like Steve Jobs and Marc Andreessen as embodiments of American masculinity and economic progress, while ignoring the implications of gender and political conservatism in Silicon Valley's culture.

items.title: An easy to read and interpret title for the article as a string.
items.author: Andrew Przybylski
items.summary:
- Andrew Przybylski, an Oxford University professor, argues that fears over 'brain rot' from technology are unfounded.
- Oxford University Press declared 'brain rot' as the word of the year, highlighting concerns about online content.
- Studies show no evidence linking screen time with negative cognitive effects in children.
- Przybylski emphasizes that living is inherently risky, and children must learn to navigate these risks responsibly.
- Historical parallels drawn between past media consumption and current digital habits.
- Technologies can also foster community and connection, enhancing overall wellbeing.
- The narrative that digital tech is depleting IQ lacks solid scientific backing and relies on anecdotal evidence.

items.title: Threat of cyber-attacks on Whitehall ‘is severe and advancing quickly’, NAO says
items.summary:
- The National Audit Office (NAO) warns of a severe risk of cyber-attacks on UK government departments, with critical IT systems vulnerable.
- An assessment found 58 critical IT systems had significant gaps in cyber-resilience; the government lacks knowledge on 228 legacy systems' vulnerabilities.
- Recent attacks include one on the British Library by a ransomware gang and another affecting NHS services, leading to significant disruptions.
- Challenges include poor coordination, staffing shortages, and reliance on outdated IT systems, with the government not meeting its cyber-defense goals by 2025.
- GCHQ highlighted a widening gap between increasing cyber threats and UK defense capabilities, naming key adversaries like China and Russia.

items.title: Chinese AI chatbot DeepSeek censors itself in realtime, users report
items.summary:
- Users report that DeepSeek, a Chinese AI chatbot, censors itself in real time while responding to queries.
- The chatbot begins by generating thoughtful responses but abruptly removes sensitive content, reflecting self-censorship under Chinese governance.
- A user experienced this firsthand while discussing free speech in China, noting that the chatbot quickly shifted from insightful commentary to refusing to engage with the topic.

items.title: What will Washington do about Chinese startup DeepSeek and its AI chatbot?
items.summary:
- The White House is investigating national security concerns surrounding DeepSeek, a Chinese AI startup.
- DeepSeek’s AI assistant app is gaining popularity in the US and UK, recently recovering from a cyberattack that limited registrations.
- The tech sector's stock market saw a decline of $1 trillion in reaction to DeepSeek’s rise, significantly affecting Nvidia’s market cap.
- DeepSeek’s app reportedly censors sensitive political topics, raising concerns about user data privacy potentially being shared with the Chinese government.
- Washington is reconsidering its approach to Chinese tech apps amid ongoing TikTok negotiations, with Trump emphasizing the need for US competitiveness.
- Sam Altman of OpenAI acknowledged DeepSeek’s R1 model as impressive, indicating a shift in the perception of AI innovation globally.

items.title: Former OpenAI safety researcher brands pace of AI development ‘terrifying’
items.author: Steven Adler
items.summary:
- Steven Adler, a former safety researcher at [OpenAI](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/openai), expresses concern about the rapid pace of AI development, calling it a "very risky gamble."
- Adler fears the race for artificial general intelligence (AGI) could have catastrophic consequences, highlighting doubts about the future of humanity.
- He notes that no research lab currently has a solution for AI alignment, raising alarms about the industry’s speed compromising safety regulations.
